All the evidence I've seen points to - partly.
 
 Genes can increase your chances of being gay. Of identical twins where one is gay (and this is from memory, I could be way off), ~90% of the time, so is the other.
 
 And of the extremely rare "identical twins separated at birth and adopted to different parents but later rediscovered as twins", where one is gay, ~60% of the time so is the other.
 
 Clearly the fact these %s are so much higher than in the broader population shows genetics have a major role. But the fact these percentage aren't 100% says something. What, I'm not sure.
 
 a) Some gay twins are still in the closet (or may not even realise they are gay?)
 
 b) There are pre-birth factors other than genetics that influence sexualty (hormones / antibodies in the mothers' body perhaps?)
 
 c) The conditions of the post-birth environment, whether chemical or external, can impact gayness.
 
 d) At some stage in life, perhaps even early on, is there any element of choice involved - even if genetics predispose us to make that choice a certain way.
 
 What are the thoughts of the gay community here?
 
 My thoughts are that the twin issues mainly relate to b), but I would like to think d) - not big on the whole absence of free will thing.

From the APA:

 
 What is sexual orientation?
 
 Sexual orientation refers to an enduring pattern of emotional, romantic, and/or sexual attractions to men, women, or both sexes. Sexual orientation also refers to a person's sense of identity based on those attractions, related behaviors, and membership in a community of others who share those attractions. Research over several decades has demonstrated that sexual orientation ranges along a continuum, from exclusive attraction to the other sex to exclusive attraction to the same sex. However, sexual orientation is usually discussed in terms of three categories: heterosexual (having emotional, romantic, or sexual attractions to members of the other sex), gay/lesbian (having emotional, romantic, or sexual attractions to members of one's own sex), and bisexual (having emotional, romantic, or sexual attractions to both men and women). This range of behaviors and attractions has been described in various cultures and nations throughout the world. Many cultures use identity labels to describe people who express these attractions. In the United States the most frequent labels are lesbians (women attracted to women), gay men (men attracted to men), and bisexual people (men or women attracted to both sexes). However, some people may use different labels or none at all.
 
 Sexual orientation is distinct from other components of sex and gender, including biological sex (the anatomical, physiological, and genetic characteristics associated with being male or female), gender identity (the psychological sense of being male or female),* and social gender role (the cultural norms that define feminine and masculine behavior).
 
 Sexual orientation is commonly discussed as if it were solely a characteristic of an individual, like biological sex, gender identity, or age. This perspective is incomplete because sexual orientation is defined in terms of relationships with others. People express their sexual orientation through behaviors with others, including such simple actions as holding hands or kissing. Thus, sexual orientation is closely tied to the intimate personal relationships that meet deeply felt needs for love, attachment, and intimacy. In addition to sexual behaviors, these bonds include nonsexual physical affection between partners, shared goals and values, mutual support, and ongoing commitment. Therefore, sexual orientation is not merely a personal characteristic within an individual. Rather, one's sexual orientation defines the group of people in which one is likely to find the satisfying and fulfilling romantic relationships that are an essential component of personal identity for many people.

 

 What causes a person to have a particular sexual orientation?
 
 There is no consensus among scientists about the exact reasons that an individual develops a heterosexual, bisexual, gay, or lesbian orientation. Although much research has examined the possible genetic, hormonal, developmental, social, and cultural influences on sexual orientation, no findings have emerged that permit scientists to conclude that sexual orientation is determined by any particular factor or factors. Many think that nature and nurture both play complex roles; most people experience little or no sense of choice about their sexual orientation.

MrWrite, you've probably heard me say before that the only way to determine whether someone is gay or not is by their own subjective self-evaluation. It is not possible to determine one's sexual orientation by observing their behavior, because if a person engaging in homosexual behavior tells you he's not gay, you can't disprove it. And similarly if a man who is married with kids says that he's living a lie and deep down he really feels gay, then there's no way to disprove it either. This is how researchers often determine if their participants are gay or not. 
 
 Of course, sometimes in addition to asking straight out what the participant's own category of sexual orientation is, qualifying questions are also asked regarding quantity, frequency and duration of sexual relations with men or women. It may be possible for a researcher to classify a participant as heterosexual (as in the case of a married man claiming to be gay on the inside), even though he classifies himself as gay.

People insist that sexual orientation is innate and permanent because any other scenario puts a dent in the idea that people are born gay. Yet we have so many situations, such as what you've listed above, where one's proclaimed sexual orientation seems to contradict their sexual behavior. And at the end of the day, it is still the individual's perogative to label himself in any manner he wants to, and any disagreement by a third party would be invasive, rude and prejudiced, so the best we can do is leave them to be happy with the label of their choice and wish them the best. 
 
 When I use the word homosexual, I describe the observable behavior, and that's it. I don't label anyone else's sexual orientation. Its not my business, nor can I accurately label anyone (including myself). So I simply don't use labels.

 Homosexuality and finger length
 
 The reasoning behind the finger-length ratios as it relates to sexual orientation is this. Babies exposed to the prenatal masculine androgen hormones develop a higher ratio of ring to index finger length. That is, an index finger shorter than the ring finger, typically found in males, is evidence of more exposure to androgens, and therefore a more masculine hand. Females typically have closer to equal ring and index finger lengths, suggesting lower androgen exposure in the womb. 
 
 For instance, a survey showed that homosexual women tend to more often have the masculine hand pattern. 
 
 Another study, also discussed in the essay above, shows that statistically males who have more older brothers are more likely to be homosexual. However, as the essay shows, men with more older brothers more often have the masculine hand pattern, suggesting that they are typically exposed to more androgens than their older brothers. Of course this contradicts the former findings about finger length as it relates to homosexuality.

All the evidence I've seen points to - partly.
 
 Genes can increase your chances of being gay. Of identical twins where one is gay (and this is from memory, I could be way off), ~90% of the time, so is the other.
 
 And of the extremely rare "identical twins separated at birth and adopted to different parents but later rediscovered as twins", where one is gay, ~60% of the time so is the other.
 
 Clearly the fact these %s are so much higher than in the broader population shows genetics have a major role. But the fact these percentage aren't 100% says something. What, I'm not sure.
 
 a) Some gay twins are still in the closet (or may not even realise they are gay?)
 
 b) There are pre-birth factors other than genetics that influence sexualty (hormones / antibodies in the mothers' body perhaps?)
 
 c) The conditions of the post-birth environment, whether chemical or external, can impact gayness.
 
 d) At some stage in life, perhaps even early on, is there any element of choice involved - even if genetics predispose us to make that choice a certain way.
 
 What are the thoughts of the gay community here?
 
 My thoughts are that the twin issues mainly relate to b), but I would like to think d) - not big on the whole absence of free will thing.

Words are just compact ways of expressing concepts that would otherwise take more words and be more awkward to express. Additionally, many words have more than one meaning, depending on the context. That doesn't mean, however, that each time a word is used it means all of its various definitions simultaneously.
 
 The words "homosexual," "heterosexual," "bisexual," and "asexual" were coined by psychologists specifically to describe the four possible sexual orientations without having to always say "sexually and/or emotionally attracted to those of..." the same, opposite, both or neither gender. As such, they are as useful for distinguishing that aspect of our psychological make-up as "tall" or "short" are for describing our general height, and make communication easier when discussing such matters.
 
 I realize that some people with their own agendas would like to have the "emotional" and "attracted" parts stricken from the record, and for the words to only refer to lust, sexual gratification, and things they consider depraved and "icky." And they've succeeded in doing so, to the extent that most--though not all--dictionaries now include a second definition referring to e.g., "homosexual behavior"... though what behaviors homosexuals engage in that heterosexuals do not, and in greater numbers, I'm sure I couldn't tell you.
 
 Dictionaries, though, do not adjudicate the meanings of words, or make them somehow "official." They merely acknowledge popular usage of them, at a given point in time. And just because some people like to play Humpty Dumpty and have words mean what they, rather than the people who coined the words, mean them to say, doesn't mean the baby should tossed out with the bathwater and the words should be no longer used in their correct contexts... especially when there are no other terms that so concisely accomplish the feat of summarizing an otherwise lengthy phrase that would become tiresome to write, read, or speak whenever the subject came up.
 
 By the way, you can now find many dictionaries that include definitions of "marriage" that do not specify it need be between between a man and a woman. So for those who like to play the "but definition #2 says..." game with "homosexual," be aware that the sword cuts both ways.

Legislators should work for a bill that represents their voting constituents. It doesn't matter if it's based on religion, secularism, atheism, or 'hoola-hoopingism'. that's the voters' prerogative. Some folks always try to preach that law can't be made based on religious interpretation. Bull. There's no way to prevent it, nor should it BE prevented. Religion deserves no less a place in the marketplace of ideas and morality than anything else. If you feel your moral basis is better, then by all means fight for it. But don't try and mis-use Separation of Church and State by asserting that religious people or their views can't play just a much a role in democracy than anything else. Morality, which motivates law, may come from any number of sources, religion included. The right to be free from religion doesn't mean (or shouldn't, anyway) that you get to stop law based on your opinion of its supporters' influences.
 
 Even the very controversial "Lemon Test", which is the supposed legal precedent left-wingers often try to invoke, doesn't prevent religion as a basis for any law. It just says it has to have a secular purpose, that it can't advance religion, and that it can't represent excessive entaglement. (How's that last one for being about as iffy and subjective as possible?) So if a legislator supports an anti-stealing law simply because his-Bible-told-him-so, there's not a dang thing you can do about it. Nor can you stop voters from doing so.
 Welcome to democracy and freedom.
